Consumer Price Index: The Cost of Living


The Consumer Price Index (CPI) is a tool to measure the change of prices paid by consumers over time. It is measured by averaging price changes for a variety of various goods and services, such as food, medical care, housing, and transportation. Though the government has data for the CPI as far back as 1913, the base years that economists use to determine the rate of change is the time frame between 1982-1984, when the CPI is at 100. Though it isn't blatantly explained why, based on research this is because this is when the Bureau of Labor Statistics was created and a time when the economy was seeing big changes, and it just was easier and convenient to start there.
